text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This revision includes the following changes:
a. IRM

- Added information on the program scope and objectives, purpose, audience, roles, management controls and terms related to the IRM content. Updated content to reﬂect new functional office name, RAAS. Subsequent subsections renumbered. b. IRM
- Moved content on IRC authority previously contained in Delegations of Authority by Treasury Regulations or Decisions to IRM
, Authority. c. IRM
- Moved content previously contained under Deviation subsection to Overview subsection. d. IRM
- Renumbered Functional Statements subsection; previously contained in IRM
No procedural changes. e. IRM

- Renamed subsection to Purpose and Contents of Delegation Orders to reﬂect content. Merged content previously contained in Other Forms of Delegation, Related Management Matters and Intent of Servicewide Delegations for Authority subsections. f. IRM
- Renumbered content on Effect of Personnel and Organizational Changes on Delegation Orders. No procedural changes. g. IRM
- Moved content previously contained in Intervening Position Authority and renamed to Documenting Intervening Position Authority in Delegation Order to reﬂect content. h. IRM
- Moved content on subsection Publicizing Delegations Orders within the and updated references to published delegation IRMs and a Servicewide delegation order on SPDER web page. i. IRM
- Moved content on Scope of Servicewide Delegation Orders, updated to IRM
and servicewide listing of delegation orders website and changed title to Servicewide Delegation Orders. Moved content previously in Note to paragraph. j. IRM
- Added subsection for Preparing and Coordinating Servicewide Delegation Orders to clarify actions in preparing Delegation Orders. k. IRM
- Added subsection on Revision and Creation of Delegation Orders to clarify process in creating and revising Delegation Orders. l. IRM
- Renumbered content on Servicewide Delegation Order Content. No changes. m. IRM
- Renumbered content on Procedures for Clearing Servicewide Delegation Orders. Added content on use of Form
and Form
to clarify process. n. IRM
- Moved content on Chief Counsel Review to individual subsection for clariﬁcation. o. IRM

- Moved content on Servicewide Delegation Order Review Package. Added to display Delegation Order package content requirements, clariﬁed content, and merged SPDER review actions within this subsection. Added inclusion of a track change ﬁle for revisions and submission of paper and electronic version of the ﬁnal review package to Added use of appropriate letterhead stationary for Commissioner/Deputy Commissioner signature. p. IRM
- Added new subsection on editorial changes of servicewide Delegation

- Renumbered content on Division/Function Delegation orders and clariﬁed guidance on the creation of Divsion/Function Delegation Orders. s. IRM

- Added subsection for Division/Function Delegation Order Clearance to clarify the clearance process. Added language requiring review by SPDER for format, numbering veriﬁcation of source of authority. t. IRM

format. w. Editorial changes throughout. Corrected references, links and updated organizational titles.

Order Process
) Purpose: This IRM section deﬁnes the official Delegation Orders of the Revenue Service and describes how to prepare, clear and issue them. (
) Audience: These procedures apply to IRS employees who are responsible developing, creating, revising and revoking IRS Delegation Orders for their Business Unit. (
) Policy Owner: The Office of Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic Resources (SPDER), is under Research, Applied Analytics and Statistics (RAAS). (
) Program Owner: SPDER is the program office responsible for overseeing Internal Management Document (IMD) process and providing guidance. (
) This IRM section enables the IRS to meet certain federal requirements to document, publish and maintain records of policies, authorities, procedures and organizational operations described in IRM
, Authority. (
) The IRS Restructuring and Reform Act of

resulted in a complete turing and reformatting of the IRM to align with IRS business processes. of the primary goals of IRS modernization was to restore and maintain the as the single, official compilation of IRS policies, procedures and guidelines. (
) In

, the IRS formed the Office of Servicewide Policy, Directives and tronic Resources (formerly Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic Research). SPDER is responsible for designing, implementing and a strategic approach to managing and setting Servicewide policy for internal management directives. See IRM
, Internal Management (IMD) and Responsibilities, for information about the affect of these changes. (
) By law, federal agencies are expected to document, publish and maintain records of policies, authorities, procedures and organizational operations. IRM is the source for the IRS. See IRM
, Authority for the and legal obligations of IMDs. (
CFR

explains delegation rules which apply to authorities set forth in the IRC. Generally, that section explains presumptions under the lation that: a. An authority is susceptible to redelegation unless prohibited or b. That delegations of authority made under the regulation directly to dinates of the Commissioner are made through the Commissioner; c. The Commissioner may select delegates in addition to those in the regulation and may condition the exercise of authority under the regulation. (
) The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA),
USC

)(c), requires each agency to maintain and make available for public inspection and copying a current index providing identifying information for the public. The publication the Delegation Orders on IRS.gov or in IRM
, Servicewide Delegations Authority fulﬁlls this legal responsibility.
Purpose: This IRM section deﬁnes the official Delegation Orders of the Internal Revenue Service and describes how to prepare, clear and issue them.
Policy Owner: The Office of Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic Resources (SPDER), is under Research, Applied Analytics and Statistics
Program Owner: SPDER is the program office responsible for overseeing the Internal Management Document (IMD) process and providing guidance.

In 1999, the IRS formed the Office of Servicewide Policy, Directives and Elec- tronic Resources (formerly Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic Research). SPDER is responsible for designing, implementing and monitoring a strategic approach to managing and setting Servicewide policy for internal management directives. See IRM 1.11.1, Internal Management (IMD) Program and Responsibilities, for information about the affect of these changes.
Internal Management Documents System
) The Director, Research, Applied Analytics and Statistics Division (RAAS) is executive responsible for the IMD program. and (
) The Director, Strategy and Business Solutions, is the program manager for SPDER. (
) Senior executives of each IRS organization are responsible for delegated thorities (i.e. Delegation Orders) for their respective programs. (
) The Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner review, approve and sign wide Delegation Orders. (
) Senior executives of each IRS organization are responsible for reviewing, maintaining and archiving Delegation Orders for their respective programs. Management (
) Beginning in FY

, SPDER will annually request the executives of each IRS organization to indicate the current status of their Delegation Order content. SPDER compiles the results into a report for Senior executives, managers, IMD coordinators, and staff which is used to support and improve IMD program management. (

) Servicewide Delegation Order - An official IRS document providing speciﬁc egations of authority issued by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, or on and Acronyms his/her behalf by either of the Deputy Commissioners, to subordinates with or without restrictions on redelegation. (

) Division/Function Delegation Order - A delegation of authority issued by Division Commissioners, Chiefs, National Taxpayer Advocate and equivalent level executives, to their subordinate officers or employees, which authorities delegated to them or their subordinates by the Commissioner or through the Commissioner via a Servicewide Delegation Order. (
) Internal Management Documents (IMDs) - Official communications that designate policies and authorities, and deliver instructions to IRS officials employees. (
) Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) - A federal law (
USC

) that the right of the public to request access to federal agency records or tion including administrative procedural manuals and instructions to staff, unless the documents are exempt from disclosure. (

) This section deﬁnes delegations of authority, describes the objectives the types of documents that are used to delegate authority, and their impact of Delegations the Service. It also describes how to prepare, clear, and issue delegation Authority orders. It contains information on how to redelegate the Commissioner’s authority by issuing Division/Function Delegation Orders; when to issue and how to number them. Note: In this IRM the term “the Commissioner” refers to the Commissioner of Internal Revenue. The term “Deputy Commissioner” refers to the Deputy Commissioner for Services and Enforcement and the Deputy for Operations Support. (
) Any deviations from the rules outlined must be approved by the Deputy Commissioner or their delegate. Deviations must be requested in
Senior executives of each IRS organization are responsible for delegated thorities (i.e. Delegation Orders) for their respective programs.
Senior executives of each IRS organization are responsible for reviewing, maintaining and archiving Delegation Orders for their respective programs.
Any deviations from the rules outlined must be approved by the Commissioner, Deputy Commissioner or their delegate. Deviations must be requested in
writing and submitted through the director of the office of Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic Resources (SPDER).

Describes a group of activities performed to achieve that division’s/ function’s mission; Provides delegation of authority to the head of the office described; May serve as a delegation of authority to subordinate officers; and Includes the authority to perform those official activities, including the issuance and signing of official documents.
Service officials are derived from: a. Statute; b. Regulations or Treasury decisions; c. Treasury Directives; d. Treasury Orders; e. Functional Statements (as published in IRM
, Organization and Staffing and as described in IRM

; and f. Intra-office letters or memoranda (signed by the Commissioner or Commissioner). Delegations of authority must be in writing through a Servicewide or Function Delegation Order and clearly establish the intent of the official. Delegations of authority are used to: a. Place authority in the position(s) where actual operational resides; b. Free officials from having to consider issues which can be handled lower levels; and c. Reduce the time and resources spent when matters are forwarded to heads of office for action that can be forwarded directly to the office instead.
Delegations of authority must be in writing through a Servicewide or Division/ Function Delegation Order and clearly establish the intent of the delegating

Place authority in the position(s) where actual operational responsibility resides; Free officials from having to consider issues which can be handled at lower levels; and Reduce the time and resources spent when matters are forwarded to heads of office for action that can be forwarded directly to the designated office instead.
Internal Management Documents System

If a supervisory official is expected to be absent for a full workday or longer, an acting supervisory official must be designated in writing or become acting when the provisions are set in applicable delegations. See IRM
for Service- wide Delegation Order

An official serving in an acting capacity may exercise the authority of the regular position and the acting position when no acting official is designated for (or automatically assumes) the regular position. Except for limitations that may be imposed in writing in a speciﬁc case or where prohibited by law, an acting official assumes the full authority vested in or delegated to that position.
Note: The same designation for a shorter absence may be made at the of the incumbent or a line superior of the incumbent.
of the incumbent or a line superior of the incumbent. (

) An official serving in an acting capacity may exercise the authority of the regular position and the acting position when no acting official is designated (or automatically assumes) the regular position. Except for limitations that be imposed in writing in a speciﬁc case or where prohibited by law, an official assumes the full authority vested in or delegated to that position. (

) Delegations of authority made by any predecessor of an incumbent will be treated as having been made by the incumbent, unless or until the modiﬁes or revokes such authority. Similarly, an incumbent assumes all au- thorities previously vested in, or delegated to, the incumbent’s position. (

) When organizational or personnel changes are made which alter title/ designation, without substantive alteration in function or duty, existing delegation orders remain in effect until updated by the appropriate organiza- tion. (

) Authority should be delegated directly to the lowest level expected to take action. Doing so avoids the need to issue redelegations of authority through heads of office. Delegating authority to the lowest level for action means a. Every intervening line supervisory position up to and including Commissioner has the same authority. Note: In some exceptional cases, delegations do not ﬂow through the chain of command. For example, certain authority delegated by Servicewide Delegation Order
, which concerns skips officials in the chain of command. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

The intervening line management positions are authorized to and direct their subordinates’ performance of the authority(ies). d. If a delegated authority is to be removed permanently, modiﬁcations the order should be sought immediately to rescind the Delegation If the restriction, suspension or removal is uniform throughout a division or function and there is in an immediate need to rescind, the executive official with supervisory authority/ownership over all of the class, must sign a memorandum documenting the restriction, pension, or removal and notify *SPDER. (

) It is important that employees know when a delegation order is issued. nators of Servicewide delegation orders must take great care to ensure that employees who need to know are informed of approval of the order. (

) A Servicewide delegation order is effective once it is reviewed, approved signed by the commissioner or deputy commissioner. It is extremely that delegation order originators confer with the SPDER staff to ensure that orders are included in IRM

Revised or new Division/Function Delegation Orders will be made available the public on the IRS public web site at recently-approved-division-function-delegation-orders, until published in the propriate section of IRM

A complete list of servicewide delegation orders can be found at the wide Delegation Order search page. Servicewide Delegation Orders redelegate the authority of the as prescribed by statute or delegated by the Secretary of the Treasury. contain authorities for headquarters, divisions/functions, administrative ties, compliance activities, data processing, submission processing, management and customer service campuses. Except in highly unusual circumstances, new or revised Servicewide tion Orders must be approved by the Commissioner or a Deputy
Except in highly unusual circumstances, new or revised Servicewide Delega- tion Orders must be approved by the Commissioner or a Deputy
Internal Management Documents System
Note: New Delegation Orders and numbering are coordinated through the program office. Contact *SPDER to request new Delegation Order number. (
) Delegation Orders are published in IRM
, Servicewide Delegations of Authority. A listing of all active Delegation Orders by business owner and number is accessible at the Servicewide Delegation Order Listing web page. (

) Respective divisions/functions are responsible for ensuring delegated authori- ties under their program scope are correctly documented in a Servicewide Delegation Order or a Division/Functional Delegation Order, as necessary. (

) Newly approved Servicewide Delegation Orders are in full force and effect mediately and supersede any preceding delegation orders found in the IRM. Newly approved Delegation Orders are posted to the Servicewide Delegation Order Listing web page and the FOIA Library on IRS.gov at uac/Recently-Approved-Commissioner-Delegation-Orders-
until published in the IRM. (

) Respective program owners and management must identify how any delega- tion order changes effect other documents and alert organization owners of changes. The changes may require an update to all associated IRM sections to keep the overall IRM consistent. (

) Senior executives are responsible for their Servicewide Delegation Orders for clearing them through impacted offices, the Office of Chief Counsel and then the Office of SPDER, prior to submitting to the Commissioner or Deputy Commissioners for approval and signature. Caution: SPDER will not process any Delegation Orders without Chief Counsel
Note: New Delegation Orders and numbering are coordinated through the SPDER program office. Contact *SPDER to request new Delegation Order number.
Caution: SPDER will not process any Delegation Orders without Chief Counsel review.
All Delegation Orders must be cleared through the Office of before forwarding to the Commissioner’s office for signature.
) Senior Executives are responsible for conducting a periodic review of Delega- tion Orders. (
) Delegation Order authors must coordinate with their organization’s IMD nator. (
) The Commissioner and Deputy Commissioners are the only officials to approve/sign a Servicewide Delegation Order. (
) When published in the related IRM section, the approval date will be printed with each Delegation Order, but a signature facsimile will not be printed.
When published in the related IRM section, the approval date will be printed with each Delegation Order, but a signature facsimile will not be printed.
Delegation Order Process 1.11.4
) Contact your organization’s IMD Coordinator for assistance in revising or (
) creating Delegation Orders. Revisions and Creation (
) For revisions, use the existing Delegation Order as your source document of Servicewide located in IRM
, Servicewide Delegations of Authority. See Exhibit Delegation Orders
for format and sample delegation orders. (
) For new Delegation Orders, contact *SPDER to obtain a number.
) Each delegation order must include the elements described below. (
) orders prepared for a division/function must contain the same elements. Servicewide Delegation

Title: Provide a brief topical title. Reﬂect the subject matter covered Order Content rather than duplicate the speciﬁc authority as stated within the order itself. Do not include any parenthetical information.

Authority: Provide a clear statement of the authority being delegated. This statement should not contain any extraneous material or although short references to important limitations may be made where prudent. A single delegation order may provide for more than one authority. The ﬁrst exhibit shows an example of a delegation order that provides for more than one authority pertaining to the same subject. Exhibit
Authority statements must never include statements dressing procedure.

Delegated to: Enter the title of the lowest level employees or positions whom the authority is delegated. All positions within the chain of command up to and including the commissioner have the same Higher grades of the same position also have the authority. Each delegation order must include the elements described below. Delegation orders prepared for a division/function must contain the same elements.

Title: Provide a brief topical title. Reﬂect the subject matter covered rather than duplicate the speciﬁc authority as stated within the order itself. Do not include any parenthetical information. Authority: Provide a clear statement of the authority being delegated. This statement should not contain any extraneous material or although short references to important limitations may be made where prudent. A single delegation order may provide for more than one authority. The ﬁrst exhibit shows an example of a delegation order that provides for more than one authority pertaining to the same subject. Authority statements must never include statements ad- dressing procedure. Delegated to: Enter the title of the lowest level employees or positions whom the authority is delegated. All positions within the chain of command up to and including the commissioner have the same authority. Higher grades of the same position also have the authority.
To determine the lowest appropriate level, originators may need to research ﬁeld responsibilities which relate to the order being prepared. If it is appropriate for employees at the GS-
level to exercise this authority and redelegations are routinely made, the Servicewide delegation order should make the del- egation to the GS-
level directly.
Note: If, during a reorganization, position titles change, without substan

tive change in responsibility, a delegation order is still effective for the new position title until the delegation order is revised. Under no circumstances should operations cease because a new title is not reﬂected in an existing delegation order.
title is not reﬂected in an existing delegation order. Redelegated to: Servicewide delegation orders must specify if redelega
tion is allowed, disallowed or restricted, and if so to what level. If the original delegation is to the lowest appropriate level, no further redelega

tion should be permitted. Sometimes Servicewide delegation orders allow a head of office or other officer to make the decision to redelegate and will provide for the lowest level to which redelegation is allowed. Note: In the case of a division/function delegation order this element must include the following statement: “This authority may not be redelegated.”

Redelegated to: Servicewide delegation orders must specify if redelega- tion is allowed, disallowed or restricted, and if so to what level. If the original delegation is to the lowest appropriate level, no further redelega- tion should be permitted. Sometimes Servicewide delegation orders allow a head of office or other officer to make the decision to redelegate and will provide for the lowest level to which redelegation is allowed.

other reference cited in a previous delegation order, in the case of revision, may be obsolete or may not be current or sufficient, so some research may be required.
Note: Where a source of authority is rendered obsolete or out
of

date, the delegation order will continue to be valid to the extent that the delegation is supported by a superseding or successor authority until the delegation order is superseded, rescinded or obsoleted.

Reminder: If a Servicewide delegation order is authorized through Treasury Order or Treasury Directive, make sure that Order/Directive is still current. Note: In the case of a Division/Function Delegation Order the source of authority will be the Servicewide delegation order(s) to which it relates.

Prior History and Ratiﬁcation Paragraph: If the delegation order revises or updates a prior delegation order, the delegation order include a statement to that effect. Additionally, all new or revised tion orders must include a ratiﬁcation statement to protect the the event that officials given the new or revised authority exercised the authority after the intent was to give them such but before the delegation order was signed. Thus, the numbered paragraph immediately preceding the signature of the approving should provide: “This order supersedes Delegation Order X-XX (Rev. XX), dated DD, YYYY. To the extent that authority previously exercised with this order may require ratiﬁcation, it is hereby affirmed and Note: If the previous order was amended after its effective date, the statement should provide, “This order supersedes Delegation Order X-XX (Rev. dated Month DD, YYYY.”

Signature and Date Lines: The bottom of the order should have adjacent lines, the ﬁrst with the approving official’s name and title below and “Date” typed under the second line. For Servicewide tion orders, the Deputy Commissioner who has organizational responsibility is the signing official.

Delegation Order Process 1.11.4
office of Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic Resources (SPDER). See IRM

, Chief Counsel Review. All Servicewide delegation orders must be sent by the originating office through their IMD coordinator to the office of SPDER. All Servicewide delegation orders must be sent to the director of SPDER prior to review and signature of the Commissioner or Deputy Commis- sioner. The SPDER office will review the document for veriﬁcation that: the sources of authority support the order and that the delegates are ap- propriately assigned. Officials clearing or reviewing a Servicewide delegation order not routed through their IMD coordinator must advise the IMD coordinator of the clearance package. The director of SPDER must be listed on the Form
, Document Clearance Record after Chief Counsel and before the Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner.

they are submitted to the SPDER office. (

calendar days of SPDER receiving the package. (
) All accepted review comments must be incorporated into the delegation before it is submitted to Chief Counsel for clearance. (
) Only changes suggested by Chief Counsel may be made after Chief approval. Caution: If
or more calendar days lapse between the review by Chief Counsel and delivery to SPDER, the delegation order package not be accepted and will be returned to be submitted into again. (

Document: Which: a. Form 2061, Document Forms 2061 documenting the Clearance Record and approval of all reviewers and reviewers’ comments their comments, including the originating organization’s Senior Executive and Chief Counsel. Note: Chief Counsel’s approval must be no more than 60 calendar days from the date received by SPDER. b. Delegation Order Process 1.11.4

) The following individuals may issue Division/Function Delegation Orders Servicewide delegation orders allow for redelegation: • Division Commissioners • Chiefs • National Taxpayer Advocate • Officers and Directors reporting to the Commissioner and/or Deputy Commissioners (
) Only the Senior executives identiﬁed in paragraph
above (also known as heads of office) can redelegate authority. (

) Division/Function Delegation Orders must be issued providing authority to lowest level. Senior executives may not issue orders that permit lower level officials to redelegate the authority. If a position held by a subordinate executive or manger is vacant or the incumbent is away from the office and unable to perform his or her delegated authorities, the authorities delegated the incumbent may be exercised by any person properly designated in to act for the incumbent. (

) A subordinate executive or manager may redelegate his or her delegated authority only when the Servicewide Delegation Order expressly provides this level of redelegation. This redelegation must be made through a Function Delegation Order signed by a Senior executive. (
) Exhibit
contains a sample of an approved Wage and Investment Division Delegation Order. (

) Every Division/Function Delegation Order is numbered. The number format identiﬁes the division/function and the related Servicewide delegation order. addition, because multiple Division/Function Delegation Orders may be relating to one particular Servicewide Delegation Order, the format allows quential numbers. Note: Some Servicewide delegation orders are so speciﬁc that there may never more than one redelegation order issued by a head of office. (
) Each Dvision/Function Delegation number will appear as follows: Organization acronym - servicewide Delegation Order number - sequential digit. Example: LB&I

) IRM

, Clearing and Approving Internal Management Documents (IMDs) describes the procedures for the clearing IMDs. However, in addition, there speciﬁc actions which apply to delegation orders. They are as follows: Order a. All Division/Function Delegation Orders must be reviewed by the origi- nating organization’s Division Counsel or Chief Counsel. b. All Division/Function Delegation Orders must be sent to SPDER for review during initial clearance. The SPDER office will review the document for numbering, format and veriﬁcation that: the sources of authority support the order and that the delegates are appropriately assigned. c. All Division/Function Delegation Orders must be signed and approved their Senior executive (head of office). (
) Business units are required to publish approved and signed Delegation Orders in IRM

within their respective Division/Function tion Order IRM section. If your organization does not have a IRM section, contact *SPDER to obtain a new IRM section number to house Orders in the your business unit Division/Function Delegation Orders. (

) In the interim of incorporating new/revised Division Delegation Orders in the IRM, the responsible program owner or business unit IMD contact must contact *SPDER to post the Division/Function Delegation Orders to the FOIA Library on IRS.gov. Once a Division/Function Delegation Order is included in the Division/Function’s Delegation order IRM section, the order must be re- moved from IRS.gov. (

) Revised or new Division/Function Delegation Orders will be made available the public on the IRS public web site at http://www.irs.gov/uac/Recently- Approved-Division-Function-Delegation-Orders, until published in the ate IRM section.

IRM 1.11.9, Clearing and Approving Internal Management Documents (IMDs) describes the procedures for the clearing IMDs. However, in addition, there are speciﬁc actions which apply to delegation orders. They are as follows:
All Division/Function Delegation Orders must be reviewed by the origi

nating organization’s Division Counsel or Chief Counsel. All Division/Function Delegation Orders must be sent to SPDER for review during initial clearance. The SPDER office will review the document for numbering, format and veriﬁcation that: the sources of authority support the order and that the delegates are appropriately assigned. All Division/Function Delegation Orders must be signed and approved their Senior executive (head of office).
) Business units are required to publish approved and signed Division/Function Delegation Orders in IRM

within their respective Division/Function Delega- tion Order IRM section. If your organization does not have a Division/Function IRM section, contact *SPDER to obtain a new IRM section number to house your business unit Division/Function Delegation Orders. (

) In the interim of incorporating new/revised Division Delegation Orders in the IRM, the responsible program owner or business unit IMD contact must contact *SPDER to post the Division/Function Delegation Orders to the FOIA Library on IRS.gov. Once a Division/Function Delegation Order is included in the Division/Function’s Delegation order IRM section, the order must be re- moved from IRS.gov. (

) Revised or new Division/Function Delegation Orders will be made available to the public on the IRS public web site at http://www.irs.gov/uac/Recently- Approved-Division-Function-Delegation-Orders, until published in the appropri- ate IRM section.
